definition: To draw someone or something closer by interest, beauty, or force.
examples: Bright flowers attract bees.
The poster attracted a lot of attention.

extra.memory_tip: Attract = ‘a track’ that pulls you in.

definition: A group of people working together on a job or vehicle; to staff or man a vehicle or activity.
examples: The film crew set up the camera. (noun)
Parents crewed the snack stall at sports day. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Crew = the team that ‘does the work’.

definition: To hang loosely and swing back and forth.
examples: Keys dangled from the hook.
He dangled his feet over the water.

definition: To move slowly without control; a slow movement from one place to another.
examples: Clouds drifted across the sky. (verb)
A drift of leaves piled against the curb. (noun)

definition: Something that happens, especially something important or organised.
examples: Sports day is our biggest school event.
The eclipse was a rare event.

definition: To start or send off; the act of starting or sending off.
examples: They will launch the new app on Monday. (verb)
We watched the rocket launch on TV. (noun)

definition: Completely different or on the other side; a thing that is completely different; on the other side.
examples: Hot is the opposite of cold. (adjective)
We sat on the opposite of the argument. (noun/adjective)
The shop is opposite the bank. (adverb)

definition: To move or turn backward; the opposite or back side; going in the opposite direction.
examples: Please reverse the car into the space. (verb)
The coin’s reverse shows a bird. (noun)

definition: A sign that gives information; to give a sign; notable or important.
examples: Wait for the green signal to cross. (noun)
She signalled for help with a torch. (verb)

definition: To guide the direction of a vehicle or course; a male bovine (young ox).
examples: Can you steer the boat while I tie the rope? (verb)
The farmer sold a young steer at the market. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Steer = ‘steer the wheel’ or a farm animal.
